text: Preface. It should be known that the Companion (Sahabi): is everyone who met the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, believing in him, and died upon that, even if apostasy occurred in between (1). The evidence that meeting the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, while believing in him is a condition for being a Companion is two proofs: The First Proof: Muslim narrated from the hadith of Abu Huraira, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "I wish we had seen our brothers." They said: Are we not your brothers, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "You are my Companions, and our brothers are those who have not come yet" (2). So the difference between his Companions and his brothers: is that he met his Companions, but did not meet his brothers. Therefore, both are believers in him, except that his Companions met him, unlike his brothers. Thus, the Companion is the one who met the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, believing in him. The Second Proof: The consensus of Ahlus-Sunnah recounted by Imam Ahmad in "Usul Al-Sunnah" (3). Indeed, Imam Ahmad recounted that whoever met the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, even for an hour, is a Companion. What he recounted in "Usul Al-Sunnah" is fundamentally agreed upon by Ahlus-Sunnah. Imam Ali

text: Section One. Defining the Point of Contention Regarding the Authority of the Companion's Madhhab. Defining the point of contention regarding the authority of the Companion's Madhhab involves four matters: First Matter: That the Companion does not contradict a text. If the Companion contradicts a text, then his saying is rejected. This was mentioned by Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah in "Majmu' Al-Fatawa" (1), Ibn Al-Qayyim in his book "I'lam Al-Muwaqqi'in" (2), and Al-Ala'i in his book "Ijmal Al-Isabah" (3). Indeed, Imam Al-Shafi'i recounted consensus on that, where he said - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -: "The scholars agreed that whoever the Sunnah of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, becomes clear to, has no right to leave it for the saying of anyone, whoever he may be" (4). Second Matter: That the Companion does not contradict another Companion. If a Companion contradicts another Companion, neither of their sayings is more worthy than the other, except what will come in the section on the Rightly Guided Caliphs - God willing -. On this is the consensus of the people of knowledge. The consensus was recounted by Al-Amidi (5), Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah as in "Majmu' Al-Fatawa" (6), and Al-Ala'i in his book "Ijmal Al-Isabah" (7), and Ibn Al-Qayyim established its foundation in his book "I'lam Al-Muwaqqi'in" (8).

text: Third Matter: That the Companion's saying does not have the ruling of being raised [to the Prophet] (Marfu'). A Companion might say a saying or do an action that has the ruling of being raised [to the Prophet]. Whatever has the ruling of being raised, the likes of it is an authority; because it is revelation, not because it is the Companion's saying. Imam Ibn Al-Qayyim - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - clarified this in his book "I'lam Al-Muwaqqi'in" (1). Fourth Matter: That the Companion's saying is not abandoned (Mahjur), meaning: that the people of knowledge do not follow the Companion. If a Companion held an opinion, and scholars agreed not to act upon this saying, then this saying is not an authority and must be left. Indeed, if scholars agreed to leave a Prophetic Hadith, this Hadith is not acted upon; because this consensus indicates either the weakness of this Hadith, or that the Hadith is abrogated. So the Companion's saying is more deserving [of being left in such a case]. Examples of this: What Al-Bazzar narrated with an authentic chain, that Abu Talha Al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him, ate hail while fasting and said: It is not food nor drink (2). This tradition, that hail does not invalidate the fasting of the fasting person, scholars have agreed on the contrary. The consensus was recounted by Ibn Al-Salah in his book "Sharh Mushkil Al-Wasit" (3), and Al-Shatibi in his book "Al-Muwafaqat" (4).

text: Section Two. Types of the Companion's Madhhab in General. If this is clear, the Companion's Madhhab in general is of two types: First Type: That the Companion's saying is famous and known. Imam Ibn Al-Qayyim - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned in his book "I'lam Al-Muwaqqi'in" (1) that if a Companion says a saying and it becomes famous, a group held that it is consensus, and another said: It is an authority but not consensus. A small group of theological jurists and later scholars held that it is neither consensus nor an authority. Then Imam Ibn Al-Qayyim refuted this - may Allah Almighty have wide mercy on him -. The evidences he mentioned for the authority of the Companion's saying will come in the second type, which is evidence that the first type is an authority a fortiori. Second Type: That the Companion's saying is not famous, or it is not known whether it became famous or not. Imam Ibn Al-Qayyim established that it is an authority. He said: This is the saying of Abu Hanifa, Malik, Ahmad, and Al-Shafi'i in the old and new [schools] (2). And he said after mentioning the quotations from Al-Shafi'i: This is the speech of Al-Shafi'i - may Allah have mercy on him and be pleased with him - textually, and we testify by Allah that he did not retract it, rather his speech in the new [school] conforms to this and agrees with it as his wording was mentioned previously (3). Because some of Al-Shafi'i's companions disagreed and said: This is not a saying of Al-Shafi'i in the new [school] (4).

text: Section Three. Two Important Premises. Before I begin mentioning the evidences for the authority of the Companion's saying, I present two extremely important premises, which are - in my view - the key to this issue: First Premise: The Companion's saying is not an authority in itself; for the Companion is not infallible in himself, evidenced by the fact that Companions differ on two opinions. So the Companion's saying is not an authority in itself, but rather it is an authority due to what is added to it, as Imam Ibn Al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, said (1). With this, a problem repeated by the Zahiris and some theologians and those influenced by them from Ahlus-Sunnah is answered. They say: How can it be said: The Companion's saying is an authority, while he is not infallible and may err? The answer to this problem is to say: This is correct, and it is not an authority in itself, but an authority due to what is added to it; that is - in approximate terms from one aspect - a form of transmitting consensus. If a Companion says a saying and is not opposed, then this is consensus, so it is an authority due to what is added to it, which is consensus. Second Premise: The Companion's saying is an authority based on prevailing conjecture (Ghalabat al-Zann). Ibn Al-Qayyim stated this in his book "I'lam Al-Muwaqqi'in" (2); that is because speculative consensus is consensus based on prevailing conjecture. For consensus is of two types: definitive and speculative. What is based on an apparent text, like His saying: {Establish prayer and give Zakat}, is definitive consensus, and what is not like that is speculative consensus. So the saying of the authority of the Companion's saying is based on prevailing conjecture. * * *

text: Section Four. Evidences for the Authority of the Companion's Saying. After these two previous premises, the evidences for the authority of the Companion's saying are as follows: First Evidence: Every evidence for the authority of the proof of consensus is evidence that the Companion's Madhhab is an authority. That is because if a Companion, or two, or three, or four... say a saying and are not opposed, then this is consensus. It is not correct for anyone to say: Such consensus is not accepted, or say what became common among theologians that this is tacit consensus (Ijma' Sukuti) and then reject it. That is because the implication of rejecting tacit consensus is that there is no consensus; because there is no spoken consensus, meaning: that every scholar uttered a saying in this issue (1). Indeed, if you wanted to prove from the people of Badr that they stated the obligation of the five prayers, you would not be able to prove that. So if you cannot do that in the five prayers, and regarding people like the people of Badr, then other issues are a fortiori. So the saying that every scholar must speak implies dropping the evidence of consensus. Ibn Qudamah, may Allah have mercy on him, mentioned this meaning in his book "Rawdat Al-Nazir" (2). Thus, the First Evidence: Every evidence indicating the authority of consensus indicates the authority of the Companion's saying. Among that: His saying Almighty: {And whoever opposes the Messenger after guidance has become clear to him and follows other than the way of the believers - We will give him what he has taken and drive him into Hell, and evil it is as a destination}. Second Evidence: Evidences specific to the Companions. I will mention two evidences: a textual traditional evidence, and an evidence from the aspect of meaning. As for the first textual traditional one: Muslim narrated from the hadith of Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The stars are trust-keepers for the heaven, so if the stars go, there comes to the heaven what it is promised. And I am a trust-keeper for my Companions, so if I go, there comes to my Companions what they are promised. And my Companions are trust-keepers for my Ummah, so if my Companions go, there comes to my Ummah what they are promised" (2). The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, likened himself to a star, and the star is used for guidance. He likened the Companions to that, indicating that they are an authority. So whoever is guided by them walks the straight path, and whoever follows their methodology is saved. This is clear evidence for the authority of the Companion's saying. Similar to that is what came regarding some Companions, as the Five except Al-Nasa'i narrated from the hadith of Al-Irbad bin Sariyah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "You must follow my Sunnah and the Sunnah of the Rightly Guided Caliphs, hold on to it with your molars" (3). This is explicit regarding the authority of the saying of some Companions, like the Rightly Guided Caliphs. Also from that is what Muslim narrated from the hadith of Abu Qatadah, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "If the people obey Abu Bakr

As for the second evidence which refers to meaning: It is what Ibn Al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, mentioned. He said: "We and the Companions share in perceptions, and they separate from us by perceptions. The perceptions by which they separate are as follows: A Companion, if he says a saying, it is possible he heard it from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him; it is possible he heard it from someone who heard it from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him; it is possible he is transmitting a consensus in their time; it is possible it is an understanding that appeared to him which did not appear to us; and it is possible - this is a fifth possibility - that it is a matter indicated by the language, and they are Imams in the chapter of language, and knew it by context, language, and other things. These five possibilities indicate that his saying is an authority. They said: There is a sixth possibility: That the Companion exercised Ijtihad and erred. But these six matters - which are the perceptions by which they separated from us - indicate that their saying is an authority based on prevailing conjecture, and prevailing conjecture is an authority in Sharia. These are perceptions by which they separated from us (2). There are perceptions in which we and they shared, but the difference between us and them in them is like the difference between the heaven and the earth. That is known by what Ibn Al-Qayyim - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned: That if one of us wants to study language, he takes a branch from his mind, while for the Companion it is his natural disposition upon which he was raised. And Hadith takes a branch from his mind, while the Companion says: I saw Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, and Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, said. And the science of Usul takes a branch from his mind, while the Companion does not need that. Until he said after that: Then if we finish all this, we arrive with minds that have become dull and tired. Some of us strive in the journey, and some of us do not strive. All this is not the case with the Companion (3).

text: Section Five. The Strongest Arguments Held by Those Who Say the Companion's Saying is Not an Authority. The strongest arguments held by those who say the Companion's saying is not an authority are two matters: First Matter: That in case of disagreement, reference is made to what Allah and the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, said. The Almighty said: {And if you disagree over anything, refer it to Allah and the Messenger}, to other evidences. They said: And Allah did not say: Refer it to Abu Bakr and Umar, nor to the Companions. This, if you look at the beginning and start of the matter, you might think strong. However, it is one of the weakest evidences. That is because the implication of saying the Companion's saying is an authority is that it is a referral to Allah and His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him. Those who said the Companion's saying is an authority only said so because evidences indicated that, this is firstly. Secondly: This implies that consensus is not an authority, so by this we agree with the Mu'tazila; because the first to deny consensus was Al-Nazzam the Mu'tazili, as mentioned by Ibn Qudamah (1), and other scholars (2). So, the requirement of returning to the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, is the saying that the Companion's saying is an authority; because the Sharia indicated this. Second Matter: That the Companions are not infallible, and may err. So how do we refer in knowing truth and falsehood, Halal and Haram, to people who may err?

text: Section Two. The Companion's Interpretation of the Text, Either by Specification, Restriction, or Clarification. This is the second division which is: That the Companion says a saying interpreting a text, either by specifying a general, restricting an absolute, or clarifying an ambiguous. What is such, is an authority; because evidences indicated the authority of the Companion's saying and did not differentiate between it being an initiation or in interpreting a text. In other words: If a general text comes, and the general text is an authority, and a specific saying of a Companion comes, and the Companion's saying is an authority as preceded, then acting by both proofs is better than neglecting one of them. Therefore, the general is specified, the absolute is restricted, and the ambiguous is clarified in such cases by the Companion's saying. Note: People of knowledge disputed much regarding the examples of this division: Is it from interpretation of the text or from the Companion contradicting the text? If it is from the Companion contradicting the text, then it is rejected; due to what preceded in defining the point of contention: That the Companion's saying is rejected if it contradicts the text by consensus. But if it is interpretation of the text, then it is an authority as established. The criterion in this is what Imam Ibn Al-Qayyim - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - established in his book "I'lam Al-Muwaqqi'in". He said, may Allah have mercy on him, in purport: If the Companion contradicts the text, another Companion must deny it upon him. So if another Companion does not deny it upon him, it is not from contradicting the text, but rather from clarifying the text (1). Therefore, if you doubt a Companion's saying whether it contradicts the text so it is rejected, or interprets it so it is accepted? Look: Did another Companion oppose him or not? If another Companion did not oppose him, it is from the interpretation and clarification of the text.

text: The evidence for this: Allah Glory be to Him said: {You are the best nation produced for mankind. You enjoin what is right and forbid what is wrong}. Ibn Al-Qayyim said: And the wrong saying is Munkar (wrong) from an aspect. If this saying was outweighed (Marjuh) according to this Companion, another Companion must deny it upon him. So when another Companion did not deny it upon him, it indicated that his saying is not outweighed, and it is not possible that Allah transmits to us the outweighed saying and leaves the preponderant saying; while He commanded us to follow the way of the believers (1). If the observer contemplates this criterion, he can distinguish between the saying that is rejected because it contradicts the text, and the saying that is accepted because it is an interpretation of the text. How much disturbance and difference there is in such matters, but if this criterion mentioned by Ibn Al-Qayyim is controlled, the matter becomes very clear, and the student and observer proceeds on a straight line without disturbance or contradiction. Before mentioning examples, let it be known that some examples might be disputed: Are they from initiating a ruling: i.e., from the first division, or from the second division? Some dispute in understanding might occur, but generally, whether it is from the first or second division, it is an authority in both cases. text: Section Three. Action if Companions Disagree. The discussion in this section is about the third division of the Companion's Madhhab, which is: What if the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, disagree on an issue? It is good to note that the default is that there is no disagreement among Companions; therefore, one must try to reconcile their sayings so that their sayings become one saying. A group of people of knowledge did that, including Ibn Qudamah - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - in "Al-Mughni" in an issue related to Sujud Al-Tilawah (1). And Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah in "Sharh Al-Umdah" (2) when he mentioned an issue and elaborated on it, he clarified - may Allah have mercy on him - that the default is that the sayings of Companions are one, so he reconciled the sayings and removed the disagreement in that. This is true, because the default in the sayings of Companions is that they are one saying, and disagreement among them is little. Their closeness to revelation and their witnessing of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, minimizes disagreement among them. But with the condition that if Companions' sayings are combined, one does not exit with a new innovated saying. If scholars differ on an issue with three sayings, and disagreement occurred among Companions, and one combined their sayings, resulting in a fourth innovated saying, this is a mistake. This division - which is what Companions differed in - has two cases: First Case: That there is evidence in the issue: If evidence appears in the issue, it is obligatory to act

That is because one must either say: It is not a proof neither in interpreting the text nor in initiating a ruling, or that it is a proof in interpreting the text and initiating a ruling. Section Two
Verifying the application of the Companion's school of thought
Two scholars or two students of knowledge might agree that the school of thought of a Companion is proof, but differ in applying that. This is a wide door, and the Usul scholars call it "Tahqiq al-Manat" (Verifying the Applicability of the Rule).
Verifying the applicability applies to two things:
One of them: Applying issues to realities: Two people might dispute in applying issues to reality. One might say: It is obligatory to act upon the saying of the Companion, while in another issue he does not act upon it; that is because the saying of the Companion was hidden from him, or he thinks it contradicts the text while it does not... etc. Therefore, we do not invalidate the principles of a scholar by his action. Ata said: The weakest knowledge is to say: 'I saw [someone doing]'. Ibn Abd al-Barr extracted it in "Jami' Bayan al-Ilm wa Fadlihi" (1). A scholar might establish principles for things but oppose that in practice. This is a wide door due to the difference among people in understanding and perception.
Sheikh al-Islam's book "Raf' al-Malam" is extremely useful in this regard. Sheikh al-Islam attributed it to the following:
First Matter: The evidence might not have reached the scholar, and in what we are dealing with, the Athar (Companion's report) did not reach him.
Second Matter: It might have reached him, but he understood it differently.
Third Matter: He might think it is abrogated (2).

Those who wasted the use of the Companion's school of thought as proof
Two groups have wasted the use of the Companion's school of thought as proof:

The First Group: The Zahiris (Literalists):
The Zahiris have innovated principles, which are five principles. Ibn al-Qayyim mentioned four in "I'lam al-Muwaqqi'in" (1), and Ibn Rajab mentioned a fifth in his explanation of Al-Bukhari (2) and his treatise "The Superiority of the Knowledge of the Salaf over the Knowledge of the Khalaf" (3). So the Zahiris went astray through five principles. The fifth principle concerns me, which is the one mentioned by Ibn Rajab in his treatise "The Superiority of the Knowledge of the Salaf over the Knowledge of the Khalaf" and in his explanation of Al-Bukhari, and Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, pointed to it in the fifth volume of his book "Minhaj al-Sunnah" (4).
That is, the Zahiris view [it permissible] to introduce a new opinion in Fiqh. So if the Companions differed on two opinions, or indeed even if the Companions agreed on an opinion, the Zahiris do not care about it and see the permissibility of introducing a new opinion. Therefore, their school is misguided, and it is a mistake to attribute it to Ahl al-Hadith. Ibn Rajab, may Allah have mercy on him, clarified this error in his treatise "The Superiority of the Knowledge of the Salaf over the Knowledge of the Khalaf" (5). Then he said: On this occasion, I invite those present among us from the Hanbalis to return to the Shafi'i Madhhab; because Al-Shafi'i is Ahmad's teacher, and he [Ahmad] is a fruit of Al-Shafi'i's fruits, so return to the Shafi'i Madhhab... This was a lesson in Tawheed (Monotheism) and he started it with fanaticism and blind imitation?!
Returning to the news of the man who said: Should I take your saying and leave the saying of Imam Ahmad who memorized a million hadith? With discussion, he said: I studied the four schools and I understand them well, but I do not leave Ahmad's school. He said: I attended Sheikh Al-Sa'di's lessons, and every saying Sheikh Al-Sa'di said contradicting Ahmad's saying, I threw it against the wall. Then I attended for a few years with Sheikh Ibn Uthaymeen, and every saying Ibn Uthaymeen said contradicting Ahmad's school, I threw it against the wall. Do you see how fanaticism is? This man did not reach what he reached directly, but rather firstly: he studied the Madhhab, then secondly: he faulted following the evidence; either because it was difficult for him or because one of his Sheikhs raised him on fanaticism in the name of grounding in Fiqh... etc.

I visited a person years ago, after he was appointed to a Sharia position. A discussion took place regarding issues of knowledge. When the dispute intensified, he would open "Al-Rawd" [a Hanbali fiqh book], read the issue, then say: The author of "Al-Rawd" says such and such, he doesn't have [in his mind]: The Prophet, peace be upon him, said...!!
Among the many words of our Sheikh Ibn Baz - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - which I heard from him repeatedly, and others heard even more, is that if it was said to him regarding an issue: Ibn Taymiyyah said such and such, how can you oppose Ibn Taymiyyah? He would say: Is he a Prophet? The consideration is the evidence. He repeated this often, may Allah have mercy on him. An interview was conducted with him where he stated about himself that he studied the Hanbali Madhhab, - then he said -: But I do not know of a single day where I gave a fatwa without evidence, whether it agreed with Ahmad's school or opposed it (1).
We should be moderate; we study the schools of thought, but we do not abandon relying on evidence, nor do we fault this. Rather, we combine both matters; because time is limited. It is possible to proceed in a way where you study one of the four schools in Fiqh and conceptualize the issues, and at the same time study it with evidence under a trustworthy scholar. Because there is no time; people are no longer as they were before, finishing "Al-Zad" in a year, studying it in a daily lesson, studying it slowly. If someone could be found who finishes "Al-Zad" in a year slowly, conceptualizing its issues, it would be beneficial to study "Al-Zad" with him, then after that launch into Ijtihad (independent reasoning) and knowing the evidence, not stopping at this limit.
The reality of many is that they start with a brief text, then intermediate, then extensive, sticking to the Madhhab. They study this for ten or fifteen years, then they slacken from looking

By saying this, we returned to closing the door of Ijtihad. They might not explicitly say the door of Ijtihad is closed, but they prevent Ijtihad on the pretext that you haven't reached it, and call for blind imitation (Taqlid) and fanaticism.
The answer to this is to say: Ijtihad is divisible. We have studied the tool of inference and deduction, and I have studied this issue, and such and such became apparent to me, and the tool of Ijtihad says such and such. So by what argument before Allah do I oppose that?
Finally: Just as fanaticism for the Zahiris in the name of Ahl al-Hadith is fought - which has begun to decrease, praise be to Allah, though it still exists - likewise fanaticism for the Madhhabs is fought. These fanatics have become types and parties fighting each other; until I saw one of them in a certain country criticizing those who explain the Hanbali Madhhab according to the method of so-and-so...

The most important results extracted from this treatise are as follows:
1 - Defining the point of dispute regarding the authority of the Companion's saying in four matters.
2 - The saying of the Companions is proof whether it became famous or not.
3 - The authority of the Companion's saying is from predominant conjecture (Zann Ghalib).
4 - Among the evidences for the authority of the Companion's saying are the evidences for the authority of Consensus.
5 - The Companions have perceptions we share with them and perceptions they are separate from us in.
6 - The saying of the Companions is proof whether in initiating a ruling or interpreting a text by specification, restriction, or clarification.
7 - The method of reconciling between the sayings of the Companions when there is disagreement.
8 - The saying of the Righteous Caliphs takes precedence over others.
9 - The Zahiris do not view the saying of the Companions as authoritative, and some people of knowledge were influenced by them.
10 - People of knowledge declaring the Zahiris as innovators and that they are not from Ahl al-Hadith.
11 - Just as Zahirism is an error, so too doctrinal fanaticism is an error like it.
